evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The two-factor interaction story involving communication/coordination breakdown among crew and mechanical/control failure is applicable and available within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as it addresses critical factors contributing to the event.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation provided by the two-factor interaction story is resistant to defeaters, as it comprehensively accounts for both human and mechanical elements, reducing the likelihood of alternative explanations undermining its validity.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: This interaction story fits key features of the incident, capturing the joint effect of human factors (communication/coordination breakdown) and technical issues (mechanical/control failure), which are essential to explaining the event's causation.

node.statement: The two-factor interaction story involving communication/coordination breakdown among crew and mechanical/control failure is applicable and available within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as it addresses critical factors contributing to the event.

assumptions: The mechanical/control failure component is present as implied by the incident description
Communication breakdown is significant enough to jointly explain the event with mechanical failure
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical/control failure alone fully explained the event without communication issues

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 directly describe communication and coordination issues among crew during pushback, supporting the applicability of the two-factor interaction story involving communication breakdown and mechanical/control failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent of mechanical/control failure contribution versus communication breakdown

node.statement: This interaction story fits key features of the incident, capturing the joint effect of human factors (communication/coordination breakdown) and technical issues (mechanical/control failure), which are essential to explaining the event's causation.

defeaters: If evidence showed the incident was caused solely by procedural deviation without communication or mechanical issues
If mechanical failure was absent or irrelevant to the event
If communication and coordination were effective and did not contribute

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H4, H8, H10, H12) directly supports that the incident involved both communication/coordination breakdown among crew and mechanical/control failure, fitting the two-factor interaction story. Discriminators favor this story over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly supports joint human and mechanical factors

node.statement: The explanation provided by the two-factor interaction story is resistant to defeaters, as it comprehensively accounts for both human and mechanical elements, reducing the likelihood of alternative explanations undermining its validity.

assumptions: The evidence provided is comprehensive regarding communication and mechanical factors.
No additional unknown factors significantly alter the explanation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that communication or coordination was flawless and fully effective, undermining the role of communication breakdown.
If mechanical/control failure alone fully explained the event without need for communication issues.
If alternative explanations with stronger evidence emerged that better explain the event.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show that communication and coordination among crew members were active but failed to prevent the mechanical/control failure event, supporting the two-factor interaction story's resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains about the completeness of communication and mechanical factors; no direct contradictory evidence is present.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution and the environmental/marking deficiency were both present and observable during the event involving Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation involving the two-factor interaction is robust against alternative explanations and counter-evidence, maintaining its validity despite potential defeaters.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The interaction between the procedural deviation and the environmental/marking deficiency aligns well with the key features of the event, accurately reflecting the contributing factors and their combined effect.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution and the environmental/marking deficiency were both present and observable during the event involving Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP size and marking adequacy as described imply environmental/marking deficiency
The continued movement beyond the TRP despite the instructor's control indicates procedural deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback was executed strictly according to procedure without deviation
If the TRP and environmental markings were clearly visible and adequate
If communication breakdown or mechanical failure were primary causes instead

Together, these directly support the claim that both procedural deviation and environmental/marking deficiency were present and observable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the exact degree of procedural deviation and environmental marking adequacy; lack of explicit contradictory evidence

node.statement: The interaction between the procedural deviation and the environmental/marking deficiency aligns well with the key features of the event, accurately reflecting the contributing factors and their combined effect.

assumptions: The TRP marking and visual signals are considered part of environmental/marking deficiency
No significant mechanical control failure or communication breakdown contributed to the event
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and marking that should have prevented the event despite procedural deviation
If mechanical failure or communication breakdown evidence better explained the event

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H7, H8, H10, H12, H13) directly supports that the procedural deviation (failure to stop at TRP) combined with environmental/marking deficiencies (small TRP, insufficient visual signals) jointly explain the event, favoring this story over communication breakdown and mechanical failure alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the relative contribution of procedural deviation versus environmental factors; lack of explicit counter-evidence for alternative stories

node.statement: The explanation involving the two-factor interaction is robust against alternative explanations and counter-evidence, maintaining its validity despite potential defeaters.

assumptions: The described procedural deviations and environmental/marking deficiencies are the primary contributors to the event.
Alternative explanations such as mechanical failure or communication breakdown are less supported by the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warning signals were given and ignored, or if mechanical failure was clearly the primary cause, this would challenge the robustness of the two-factor interaction explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H6, H7, H9, H10, and H12 directly document the procedural deviation in pushback execution in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 dataset, showing the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence, confirming consistent observability and documentation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No significant ambiguity; evidence is direct and detailed

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H1, H2, H8, H10, H12) shows procedural deviation in pushback execution and communication breakdown among crew, supporting the two-factor interaction story. Discriminators favor this story over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in exact communication details and possible unreported factors

If environment or marking deficiencies were shown to be the primary cause

The interaction between crew communication/coordination breakdown and environmental/marking deficiencies aligns with the key features of the event, accurately reflecting the contributing factors and their joint impact.

S2__R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN__R4_MECHA.statement: The two-factor interaction story involving communication/coordination breakdown among crew and mechanical/control failure is applicable and available within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as it addresses critical factors contributing to the event.

The explanation provided by the two-factor interaction story is resistant to defeaters, as it comprehensively accounts for both human and mechanical elements, reducing the likelihood of alternative explanations undermining its validity.

This interaction story fits key features of the incident, capturing the joint effect of human factors (communication/coordination breakdown) and technical issues (mechanical/control failure), which are essential to explaining the event's causation.

S2__R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY.statement: The two-factor interaction story involving Environmental/marking deficiency and Mechanical/control failure is available and applicable within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:cardinality_experiment:story_cardinality_k2 scope.

The two-factor interaction story is resistant to defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:cardinality_experiment:story_cardinality_k2 scope, maintaining explanatory power against alternative explanations or counter-evidence.

The story accurately fits the key features observed in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:cardinality_experiment:story_cardinality_k2, demonstrating how the interaction of Environmental/marking deficiency and Mechanical/control failure jointly explain the event.
